text: The priest will make atonement for the person who erred unintentionally, since by that unintentional error he sinned against the Lord. When the priest makes atonement for him, he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall have a single law for anyone who commits an error unintentionally, whether a native-born Israelite or an alien who resides among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a person who does anything defiantly, whether he is native-born or an alien, is blaspheming the Lord. That person must be cut off from among his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he has despised the Lord’s word and has broken his commands, that person will be completely cut off. His guilt shall remain on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Israelites were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses, Aaron, and the entire community.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put him in custody, because it had not been made clear what should be done with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “The man must certainly be put to death. The entire community is to stone him outside of the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire community brought him outside of the camp and stoned him to death, just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Moses
speaker: Narrator

text:
to speak to the Israelites and tell them this:
Throughout their generations to come, they are to make tassels on the corners of their garments. They are to put a blue cord on the tassels on each corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: These tassels are to be there for you so that when you see them, you will remember all of the Lord’s commands, and you will carry them out. Then you will not prostitute yourselves by chasing after your own heart and your own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: This way you will remember and carry out all of my commands and be holy to your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Korah, who was the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, joined with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and with On, the son of Peleth. These three were descendants of Reuben. They gathered
speaker: Narrator

text: two hundred fifty well-known Israelites, tribal chiefs of the community, appointed representatives who served on the council, and they rose up against Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They assembled together against Moses and Aaron and said to them, “You have gone too far! For the entire community is holy, every one of them, and the Lord is among them! Why do you lift yourselves up above the Lord’s assembly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this, he fell facedown.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Korah and to all his followers, “In the morning the Lord will reveal which of you are his and which of you are holy, and he will have that person come near to him. The man he chooses, he will have that man come near to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this, Korah, you and all your followers. Take censers,
speaker: Narrator

text: put fire in them, and place incense on them in the presence of the Lord tomorrow. The man whom the Lord chooses will be set aside as holy. You have gone too far, you Levites!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Korah, “Listen, you Levites!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough for you that the God of Israel has separated you from the Israelite community and brought you near to himself to do the work of the Lord’s Dwelling and to stand before the congregation to minister to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that he has brought you near, along with all your fellow Levites who are with you? Do you seek the priesthood also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you and all your followers have gathered together against the Lord! As for Aaron, who is he that you should grumble against him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent to summon Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, but they said, “We will not come!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to have us die in the wilderness? Must you also make yourself a ruler over us?
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides this, you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey. You have not given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Will you gouge out the eyes of these men? We will not come up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was very angry and said to the Lord, “Do not pay attention to their offering. I have not taken a single donkey from them, nor have I wronged any one of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Korah, “Tomorrow, you and all your followers are to appear before the Lord—you and they, and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every one of them is to take his censer and put incense on it, and each man will present his censer before the Lord, two hundred fifty censers. You and Aaron also, each one of you, will present his censer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They each took their own censers, put fire in them, placed incense on them, and stood at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting with Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah assembled the entire community opposite Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. The glory of the Lord appeared to the entire assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Separate yourselves from this assembly so that I may put an end to them instantly!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses and Aaron fell facedown and said, “O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, when one man sins, will you be angry against the entire community?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the assembly, ‘Move away from the dwelling of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram. The elders of Israel followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the assembly, “Move back from the tents of these wicked men. Do not touch anything that belongs to them, or you will be swept away because of all their sins!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So from every side, they moved away from the dwelling of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrance to their tents with their wives, children, and little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is how you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these things and that all this was not just my idea.
speaker: Narrator

text: If these men die a death like everyone else and if they suffer the same fate that everyone does, then the Lord has not sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the Lord creates something unheard of and the ground opens its mouth and swallows them up with everything that belongs to them, and they go down alive into the grave, you will know that these men have treated the Lord with contempt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he finished speaking all these words, the ground beneath them split open.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed up everyone who was with Korah, along with their households and all their possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they and everything that belonged to them went down alive into the grave. The earth closed up over them, and they disappeared from the midst of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearing their screams, all the Israelites who were around them fled, because they said, “The earth will swallow us up too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Fire went out from the Lord and consumed the two hundred fifty men who offered the incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest to remove the censers from the burning debris and scatter the fire far away, for the censers are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the censers belonging to those who sinned at the cost of their own lives into hammered sheets for plating the altar, because they presented them before the Lord, and the censers are holy. They will serve as a sign to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers, which had been presented by those who had been burned up by fire. They hammered them into plating for the altar
speaker: Narrator

text: as a reminder to the Israelites that no unauthorized person, who is not from the descendants of Aaron, should come near to burn incense before the Lord and become like Korah and his followers. Eleazar the priest did just as the Lord said to him through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the next day the entire Israelite community grumbled against Moses and Aaron. They said, “You have killed the people of the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the community assembled together against Moses and Aaron and turned toward the Tent of Meeting, the cloud covered it, and the Glory of the Lord appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went in front of the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from this community so that I may put an end to them instantly!” Moses and Aaron fell facedown to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take your censer, put fire from the altar in it, place incense on it, go quickly to the community, and make atonement for them, because wrath has gone out from the Lord! The plague has begun.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron did as Moses said and ran into the middle of the assembly. The plague had already begun among the people. He put the incense on his censer and made atonement for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between the dead and the living, and the plague was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now those who died by the plague totaled 14,700, besides those who died because of the offense of Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, and the plague was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, and collect staffs from them, one from each father’s house, from all their tribal chiefs according to their fathers’ houses, twelve staffs in all. Write each man’s name on his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write Aaron’s name on the staff of Levi, because there will be one staff for each head of their fathers’ houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to place them in the Tent of Meeting before the Testimony, where I meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The staff of the man whom I will choose will sprout. I will rid myself of the Israelites’ constant grumbling against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites, and each one of their tribal chiefs gave him a staff, one staff for each tribal chief according to their fathers’ houses, twelve staffs in all. Aaron’s staff was among their staffs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses placed the staffs before the Lord in the Tent of the Testimony.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day Moses went into the Tent of the Testimony and discovered that Aaron’s staff representing the house of Levi had sprouted, budded, blossomed, and produced almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought out all the staffs from the Lord’s presence to all the Israelites. They looked, and each man took his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Put Aaron’s staff back in front of the Testimony to be kept as a sign against the rebellious. In this way you will put an end to their grumblings against me, so that they do not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That is what Moses did. He did just as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Moses, “Look, we are perishing! We are lost! We are all lost!
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who approaches the Lord’s Dwelling dies! Must we all perish?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord gave these directions to Aaron:
You, your sons, and your father’s house with you will bear the guilt for any sins in connection with the sanctuary. You and your sons with you will bear the guilt for any sins in connection with your priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also have your brothers from the tribe of Levi, your father’s tribe, come forward with you so that they may join you and assist you when you and your sons along with you are on duty in front of the Tent of the Testimony.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will perform the duties for you and for the entire tent. However, they are not to go close to the furnishings in the sanctuary or to the altar, so that they and you will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to join you and perform the duties for the Tent of Meeting, to do all the work at the tent. No unauthorized person is to go near you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to perform the duties for the sanctuary and for the altar so that there will not be any more wrath on the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I myself have taken your brothers, the Levites, from among the Israelites. They are a gift to you, given by the Lord, to do the work at the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you and your sons with you will keep watch over your priesthood in connection with everything at the altar and inside the veil. You are to do this work. I am giving you your priesthood as a gift. Any unauthorized person who comes near must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord spoke to Aaron. This is what he said:
See, I myself have put you in charge of the elevated offerings made to me. All of the holy things from the Israelites I have given to you as an allotment and to your sons as a permanent right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Part of the most holy things that are not burned in the fire will be yours. Every one of their offerings which they give to me—every one of their grain offerings, every one of their sin offerings, and every one of their restitution offerings—will be most holy for you and your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat it as a most holy thing. Every male may eat of it. It will be holy for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is yours too: the elevated offerings from their gifts, including all the wave offerings from the Israelites. I have given them to you and to your sons and daughters with you as a permanent right. Everyone who is ceremonially clean in your house may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the best oil, all the best wine and grain, the Israelites’ firstfruits which they give to the Lord, I have given them all to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first ripe produce from everything that is in their land, all that they bring to the Lord, will be yours. Everyone who is ceremonially clean in your house may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything permanently devoted by the Israelites will be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn from every living thing, human or animal, whatever they present to the Lord, will be yours. However, you must redeem the firstborn of any human. You must also redeem the firstborn of an unclean animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they are one month old, you must redeem them at the set redemption price, five shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel, which weighs twenty gerahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you may not redeem the firstborn of the cattle, sheep, or goats. They are set aside as holy. You will splash their blood on the altar and turn their fat into smoke as an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their meat will be yours. It will be yours just like the breast of the wave offering and the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the elevated offerings of holy things, which the Israelites lift up to the Lord, I have given to you and to your sons and daughters with you as a permanent allotment. It is a permanent covenant of salt before the Lord for you and your descendants with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord also said these things to Aaron:
You will not have any allotment of land among them in the land, and you will not have any share among them. I am your share and your possession among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have given all the tithes in Israel to the Levites as a possession in return for their work which they are doing, the work at the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites will never again come near the Tent of Meeting. If they do, they will become responsible for sin and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites are to do the work at the Tent of Meeting, and they will bear their guilt. It will be a permanent regulation throughout your generations to come: They will not have any possession among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the tithe from the Israelites, which they lift up as an elevated offering for the Lord, I have given to the Levites as a possession. Therefore I have said to them, “They will not have any possession among the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Moses
speaker: Narrator

text:
to speak to the Levites and tell them this:
When you receive from the Israelites the tithe, which I have given to you as your possession, you will lift up an elevated offering from it for the Lord, a tenth of the tithe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your elevated offering will be credited to you, as if it were grain from the threshing floor and abundance from the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you also are to lift up an elevated offering for the Lord from every one of the tithes which you receive from the Israelites. From the tithes, you will give the elevated offering for the Lord to Aaron the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will lift up every elevated offering for the Lord from the things given to you, from all the best, the holiest part of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell the Levites this:
When you lift up the best part of the offering, it will be credited to the Levites as if it were produce from the threshing floor and the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat it anywhere, with your household, for it is your wages in return for your work at the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not become responsible for sin in regard to it when you lift up the best part of it. You will not defile the holy things from the Israelites, and you will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are requirements of the law which the Lord has commanded.
Tell the Israelites to bring you a red heifer without blemish, one that has no defect and that has never been under a yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to give it to Eleazar the priest. He is to have it taken outside of the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his finger Eleazar the priest is to take some of its blood and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heifer is to be burned in his sight. Its hide, flesh, and blood are to be burned along with its manure.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet yarn and throw them onto the burning heifer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will wash his clothes and bathe his flesh in water. Afterward he will come into the camp, and the priest will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who burns the heifer is to wash his clothing in water and bathe his flesh in water. He will remain unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who is ceremonially clean is to gather up the heifer’s ashes and place them outside of the camp in a clean place. They will be kept for the Israelite congregation to use to make the water for removing impurity. It is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who gathers the heifer’s ashes is to wash his clothes and be unclean until evening. This will be a permanent regulation for the Israelites and the aliens residing among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever touches the body of a dead person will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to purify himself with the water on the third day, and he will become clean on the seventh day. But if he does not purify himself on the third day, then he will not become clean on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches a dead human body but does not purify himself defiles the Lord’s Dwelling. That person must be cut off from Israel. He is unclean, because he has not sprinkled himself with the water for removing impurity. His uncleanness is still on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law when someone dies in a tent: Everyone who comes into the tent and everyone who is in the tent will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every open container without a lid on it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone in the open countryside who touches someone killed by a sword or someone who has died, or anyone who touches a human bone or a grave, will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the unclean person, take some of the ashes from the burnt sin offering, put them into a vessel, and add water from a flowing source to the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A ceremonially clean person is to take hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle the water on the tent, on all the items, and on the people who were there. He is also to sprinkle it on anyone who has touched someone who was killed or someone who has died and on anyone who has touched a grave or a human bone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ceremonially clean person will sprinkle the unclean person on the third day and on the seventh day. On the seventh day, after the ceremonially clean person has purified the unclean person, that person will wash his clothes and bathe himself in water, and he will be clean at evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone who is unclean and refuses to purify himself will be cut off from the midst of the assembly, because he has defiled the sanctuary of the Lord. The water for removing impurity was not sprinkled on him, so he remains unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be a permanent regulation for them. The one who sprinkles the water for removing impurity shall wash his clothing, and whoever touches the water for removing impurity will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that the unclean person touches will be unclean, and the person who touches those things will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel, the entire community, came to the Wilderness of Zin in the first month, and the people stayed at Kadesh. Miriam died there and was buried there.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no water for the community, so they assembled together against Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people quarreled with Moses and said, “If only we had perished when our brothers perished before the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought the Lord’s assembly into this wilderness for us and our livestock to die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you taken us up out of Egypt to bring us into this horrible place? This place does not have grain, figs, vines, or pomegranates. There is no water to drink!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went from the presence of the assembly to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. They fell facedown. The Glory of the Lord appeared to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the staff and assemble the community. You and Aaron, your brother, speak to the rock before their eyes, and it will pour out its water. You will bring water for them from the rock and provide water for the community and their livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the staff from the Lord’s presence just as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron gathered the assembly together before the rock, and he said to them, “Listen now, you rebels! Must we bring water out of this rock for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses lifted up his hand and struck the rock with his staff two times, and a great amount of water gushed out. The congregation and their livestock drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust me enough to honor me as holy in the eyes of the Israelites, therefore you will not bring this assembly into this land which I have given to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the waters of Meribah, because there the Israelites quarreled with the Lord, and through them he showed himself to be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom to say, “This is what your brother Israel says: You know all the hardship that has come upon us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestors went down to Egypt, and we lived in Egypt for a long time. The Egyptians mistreated us and our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we cried to the Lord, he heard our voice, sent an angel, and brought us out of Egypt. So look, here we are in Kadesh, a city on the edge of your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let us pass through your land. We will not pass through any field or vineyard. We will not drink water from any well. We will go on the King’s Highway. We will not turn to the right or to the left until we have passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom said to him, “You must not pass through our territory, or we will go out to meet you with the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to them, “We will go up on the main road. If we drink your water, we and our herds of livestock, then we will pay for it. Just let us pass through on foot, nothing else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom said, “You will not pass through.” Edom went out to meet them with a large force of many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom refused to give Israel passage through their territory, so Israel turned away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire community of the Israelites set out from Kadesh and came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor along the border of Edom’s territory. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron will be gathered to his people, because he cannot enter into the land which I have given to the Israelites, because you rebelled against my command at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take Aaron and Eleazar his son and bring them up to the top of Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove Aaron’s garments and put them on Eleazar his son. Aaron will be gathered to his fathers and die there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did just as the Lord commanded. They went up to the top of Mount Hor in the sight of the entire community.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses removed Aaron’s garments and put them on Eleazar his son. Aaron died there on the top of the mountain, and Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the entire community saw that Aaron had passed away, the entire house of Israel wept for Aaron for thirty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming on the road to Atharim. He fought against Israel and captured some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel made this vow to the Lord: “If you will indeed give these people into our hands, then we will totally destroy their cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord listened to Israel’s voice and gave the Canaanites into their hands. The Israelites totally destroyed them and their cities. They named the place Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Mount Hor along the road to the Red Sea to go around the land of Edom, but the people became very impatient along the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people spoke against God and against Moses, “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? Look, there is no food! There is no water! And we are disgusted by this worthless food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent venomous snakes among the people, and the snakes bit the people. As a result many people from Israel died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people went to Moses and said, “We have sinned, because we have spoken against the Lord and against you. Pray to the Lord to take the snakes away from us.” So Moses prayed on behalf of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Make a venomous snake and put it on a pole. If anyone who is bitten looks at it, he will live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses made a bronze snake and put it on the pole. If a snake had bitten anyone, if that person looked at the bronze snake, he lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites set out and camped at Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, in the wilderness that faces Moab, toward the sunrise.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they set out and camped at the Zered Canyon.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they set out and camped on the other side of the Arnon, in the wilderness that extends from the Amorite border. (The Arnon is the border between Moab and the Amorites.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this reason it says in the Book of the Wars of the Lord:
Waheb in Suphah, the ravines of the Arnon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sloping ravines that bend toward the settlement of Ar and lie on the border of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they continued to Be’er. That is the well which the Lord spoke about to Moses: “Gather the people together, and I will give them water.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Israel sang this song:
Spring up, O well! Sing about it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing about the well which the officials dug,
which the nobles of the people hollowed out
    with their scepters and their staffs.
From the wilderness they continued to Mattanah,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Bamoth to the valley in the region of Moab by the top of Pisgah that overlooks the wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites to say,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Permit us to pass through your land. We will not turn aside into any field or vineyard. We will not drink the water from any well. We will stay on the King’s Highway until we have passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. Instead Sihon gathered all his people together and went out into the wilderness to confront Israel. When he came to Jahaz, he fought against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel struck him with the sword and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, but only as far as the Ammonites, because the Ammonite border was strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel took all these cities. Israel began living in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon and in all its villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Heshbon had been the city of Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and taken from him all his land as far as the Arnon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore the poets say,
Come to Heshbon.
Let the city of Sihon be built and established,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for a fire has gone out of Heshbon,
a flame from the town of Sihon.
It has consumed Ar of Moab
and engulfed the heights of the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you, Moab!
You are destroyed, people of Chemosh!
He has given up his sons as refugees,
and his daughters go into captivity
to Sihon king of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We overthrew them.
Heshbon is destroyed as far as Dibon.
We have laid waste as far as Nophah.
Fire reaches as far as Medeba.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel lived in the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent spies to Jazer. They took its towns and drove out the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They turned and went up on the road to Bashan. Og king of Bashan came out with all his people to confront Israel in battle at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Do not be afraid of him, for I have delivered him into your hand along with all his people and his land. You will do to him just as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived at Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they struck him down along with his sons and all his people until there were no survivors. Then they took possession of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites set out and camped on the Plains of Moab along the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak son of Zippor saw everything that Israel had done to the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moab was afraid of the people, because they were so numerous. Moab was terrified because of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab said to the elders of Midian, “Now this assembly will eat up everything around us, just as cattle eat up the grass in the field.”
Balak son of Zippor was king of Moab at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent messengers to summon Balaam, the son of Beor, from Pethor by the Euphrates River, in the land of his own people.
He said, “Look, a people came out of Egypt. They cover the surface of the land, and they are settling right across from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please come now. Curse this people for me, for they are more powerful than I am. Perhaps I will succeed and strike them down, driving them out of the land, for I know that whomever you bless is blessed, and whomever you curse is cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Moab and the elders of Midian went with payments for his occult practices in their hand. They came to Balaam and told him what Balak said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to them, “Spend the night here, and I will report to you what the Lord says to me.” So the Moabite officials stayed with Balaam.
speaker: Narrator

text: God came to Balaam and said, “Who are these men with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to God, “Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, sent messengers to me, who said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Look, the people that has come out of Egypt covers the surface of the land. Now, come, curse them for me. Perhaps I will be able to fight against them and drive them out.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Balaam, “You are not to go with them. You are not to curse the people, for they are blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam got up in the morning and said to Balak’s officials, “Go back to your land, because the Lord has refused to let me go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials of Moab got up and went back to Balak. They said, “Balaam refuses to come with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak again sent other officials, more numerous and more prestigious than the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to Balaam and said to him, “This is what Balak son of Zippor says, ‘Do not let anything prevent you from coming to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I will reward you very richly. Also I will do whatever you tell me. Just come and curse this people for me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam responded to Balak’s servants, “Even if Balak would give to me his house full of silver and gold, I would not be able to go against the command of the Lord my God to do anything small or great.
speaker: Narrator

text: But please, stay and spend the night here, and I will find out what else the Lord might say to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God came to Balaam at night and said to him, “If the men have come to summon you, get up and go with them. However, do only what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam got up in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the officials of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God’s anger burned because Balaam was going with them. So the Angel of the Lord stood in the road to oppose him. Balaam was riding on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw the Angel of the Lord standing in the road, with his drawn sword in his hand. So the donkey turned off the road and went into the field. Balaam struck the donkey to make it turn back to the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Angel of the Lord stood in a narrow path between the vineyards with walls on both sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw the Angel of the Lord and pressed against the wall and squeezed Balaam’s foot against the wall. Balaam struck the donkey again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Angel of the Lord went ahead and stood in a narrow place where there was no room to turn to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw the Angel of the Lord and lay down under Balaam. Balaam’s anger burned, and he struck the donkey with his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord opened the mouth of the donkey, which said to Balaam, “What have I done to you that you have struck me these three times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the donkey, “Because you have made a fool of me! If only there was a sword in my hand, I would kill you now!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The donkey said to Balaam, “Am I not your donkey, the one you have always ridden to this day? Is this what I usually do to you?”
He said, “No.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the Angel of the Lord standing in the road, with his drawn sword in his hand. Balaam knelt and bowed with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Angel of the Lord said to him, “Why have you struck your donkey these three times? Look, I myself have come out to oppose you, because your way is reckless before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw me and turned away from me these three times. If it had not turned away from me, I would have surely killed you by now and let the donkey live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the Angel of the Lord, “I have sinned, for I didn’t know that you stood in the road to confront me. Now if this is displeasing to you, I will go back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Angel of the Lord said to Balaam, “Go with the men, but you will speak only the words that I speak to you.” So Balaam went with Balak’s officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balak heard that Balaam had come, he went out to meet him at the Moabite town on the Arnon border at the edge of his territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Didn’t I send for you urgently when I summoned you? Why didn’t you come to me? Don’t you know that I can really reward you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Look, I have come to you now. But am I really able to say anything? I will speak only the words that God puts in my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam went with Balak, and they came to Kiriath Huzoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak sacrificed cattle and sheep and sent for Balaam and the officials who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, Balak took Balaam and brought him up to Bamoth Baal. From there, he saw the outskirts of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars for me here and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did just as Balaam had said. Balak and Balaam offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stand here by your burnt offering, while I go off by myself. Perhaps the Lord will come to meet me. Whatever he shows me I will tell you.” ⎣So Balak went and stood by his burnt offering, and Balaam called to God⎦ and then he went off to a barren hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: God met Balaam, and Balaam said to him, “I have set up seven altars, and I have offered up a bull and a ram on each altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord put a message into Balaam’s mouth and said, “Return to Balak, and you are to deliver this message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam returned to Balak and found him standing by his burnt offering, along with all the officials of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Balaam took up his oracle. He said:
From Aram, Balak has brought me.
Balak, the king of Moab from the eastern mountains, said,
“Come, curse Jacob for me.
Come, denounce Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can I curse someone God has not cursed?
How can I denounce someone the Lord has not denounced?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, from the rocky peaks I see him.
From the hills I look at him.
Look! A people that dwells apart,
that does not consider itself to be one of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can count the dust of Jacob,
or number even a fourth of Israel?
May I die the death of the righteous!
May my final end be like his!
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, but you have just blessed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “Don’t I have to speak accurately whatever the Lord puts in my mouth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Please come with me to another place where you can see them. You will see only their outskirts. You will not see all of them. From there curse them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak took Balaam into the field of Zophim, to the top of Pisgah. Balak built seven altars and offered up a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stand here by your burnt offering, while I meet the Lord over there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord met with Balaam and put a message in his mouth. The Lord said, “Return to Balak, and you are to deliver this message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam came back to Balak and found him standing by his burnt offering, and the officials of Moab were with him. Balak said to him, “What did the Lord say?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Balaam took up his oracle and said:
Get up, Balak, and listen!
Give ear to me, son of Zippor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is not a man, that he should lie,
nor a son of man, that he changes his mind.
Does he say something, and then not carry it out?
Does he speak, and then not bring it about?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, I have received a command to bless.
He has blessed, and I cannot change that.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No disaster is in sight for Jacob.
No suffering is seen in Israel.
The Lord his God is with him.
The shout for the King is among them.
He rejoices in his King.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God brings them out of Egypt.
God is like the horns of a wild ox for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely there is no occult power against Jacob,
no omen against Israel.
They will say about Jacob and Israel,
“What great things God has done!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, the people rise up like a lioness.
Like a lion they lift themselves up.
He will not lie down until he eats the prey,
until he drinks the blood of the slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “Do not curse them at all! Do not bless them at all!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Balaam answered Balak, “Didn’t I say to you that I must do everything the Lord says?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Come on, I will take you to another place. Maybe God will agree to let you curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, which overlooks the wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars for me here and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did just as Balaam had said and offered up a bull and a ram on every altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not go to look for omens as he had done at the other times, but he set his face toward the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam lifted up his eyes and saw Israel dwelling according to their tribes, the Spirit of God was upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took up his oracle and said:
The declaration of Balaam son of Beor,
the declaration of the man whose eye is open,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the declaration of the one who hears the words of God,
who sees the vision of the Almighty,
who is falling down, but his eyes are wide open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are your tents, O Jacob,
        and your dwelling places, O Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like rows of palm trees they stretch out,
        like gardens by the riverside,
        like aloes which the Lord has planted,
        like cedar trees beside the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Water will flow from his buckets.
        His seed will have abundant waters.
        His king will be higher than Agag.
        His kingdom will be lifted up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God brings him out of Egypt.
        God is like the horns of a wild ox for him.
        He will eat up the nations who are his adversaries.
        He will gnaw on their bones.
        He will pierce them through with his arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He crouches like a lion.
        He lies down like a lioness.
        Who will rouse him?
        The one who blesses you is blessed.
        The one who curses you is cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak’s anger burned against Balaam, and he slapped his hands together. Balak said to Balaam, “I summoned you to curse my enemies, but look, all you have done is bless them these three times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get out of here. Go to your own place! I said I would really reward you, but look, the Lord has denied you a reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Didn’t I tell the messengers you sent to me, ‘I will say what the Lord says.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, I can’t go against the command of the Lord by doing anything good or bad of my own will’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, I am going back to my people, but pay attention now—I will tell you what this people will do to your people in days to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Balaam took up his oracle and said:
The declaration of Balaam son of Beor,
the declaration of the man whose eye is open,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the declaration of the one who hears the words of God,
who receives knowledge from the Most High,
who sees the vision of the Almighty,
who is falling down, but his eyes are wide open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
I see him, but not now.
        I behold him, but not near.
        A star will come out of Jacob.
        A scepter will rise up out of Israel.
        It will smash the foreheads of Moab
        and the skulls of all the people of Sheth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Edom will lose its territory to others.
        Seir, Israel’s enemy, also will become a possession,
        but Israel will display its power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who comes from Jacob will rule,
        and he will destroy the survivors of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He looked at Amalek, took up his oracle, and said:
First among the nations was Amalek,
but his end will come to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He looked at the Kenites, took up his oracle, and said:
Permanent is your dwelling place.
Set in stone is your nest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, you Kenites will be destroyed,
    when Ashshur takes you captive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took up his oracle and said:
Ah, who will live when God does this?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But ships will come from the coast of Kittim.
They will oppress Ashshur.
They will oppress Eber.
But they also will come to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam got up and left to return to his place. Balak also went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Israel stayed in Shittim, the people started to commit sexual immorality with the women of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: The women invited the people to the sacrifices for their gods. The people ate and bowed down to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites attached themselves to the Baal of Peor. The Lord’s anger burned against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take all the heads of the people and impale them before the Lord in broad daylight so that the fierce anger of the Lord may turn away from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the judges of Israel, “Each of you must kill any of his men who have attached themselves to the Baal of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, an Israelite man came and brought a Midianite woman to his brothers in the sight of Moses and the entire Israelite community, while the people were weeping at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, saw this, he rose up from the middle of the assembly and took a spear in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed the Israelite man into the large tent and ran both of them through, the Israelite man and the woman, right through her belly. Then the plague against the Israelites was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who died by the plague were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, has turned my wrath away from the Israelites, because he was very zealous for me among you. So I did not put an end to the Israelites in my zeal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore say, ‘Look, I myself will give to him my covenant of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his descendants after him will have the covenant of a permanent priesthood, because he was zealous for his God and made atonement for the Israelites.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Israelite man who was struck dead, who was struck dead with the Midianite woman, was Zimri son of Salu, a tribal chief of the father’s house for the Simeonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Midianite woman who was struck dead was Cozbi, the daughter of Zur, who was a tribal head of a father’s house in Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and said, ⎣“Speak to the Israelites, saying,⎦
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Treat the Midianites as enemies and strike them dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they treated you as enemies when they deceived you with their treachery in the incident involving Peor and Cozbi, the daughter of the Midianite tribal chief, their sister, who was struck dead on the day of the plague in the Peor incident.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the plague, the Lord spoke to Moses and Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the entire Israelite community, twenty years old and up, according to their fathers’ houses, all who are of age to serve in Israel’s army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke with them on the Plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Take a census of the men twenty years old and up, just as the Lord commanded Moses.”
These are the Israelites who came out from the land of Egypt:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben was Israel’s firstborn. The male descendants of Reuben were: from Hanok, the Hanokite clan; from Pallu, the Palluite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Hezron, the Hezronite clan; from Karmi, the Karmite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the Reubenite clans. Those who were registered totaled 43,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Pallu was Eliab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram.
(These were the same Dathan and Abiram who were chosen leaders of the community who fought against Moses and Aaron along with the followers of Korah, when they fought against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up together with Korah, when his followers died and when the fire consumed the two hundred fifty men. So they became a warning sign.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the sons of Korah did not die out.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Simeon according to their clans were: from Nemuel, the Nemuelite clan; from Jamin, the Jaminite clan; from Jakin, the Jakinite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Zerah, the Zerahite clan; from Shaul, the Shaulite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These Simeonite clans totaled 22,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Gad according to their clans were: from Zephon, the Zephonite clan; from Haggi, the Haggite clan; from Shuni, the Shunite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Ozni, the Oznite clan; from Eri, the Erite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Arodi, the Arodite clan; from Areli, the Arelite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These clans of the descendants of Gad who were registered totaled 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: Er and Onan were sons of Judah. Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Judah according to their clans were: from Shelah, the Shelanite clan; from Perez, the Perezite clan; from Zerah, the Zerahite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Perez were: from Hezron, the Hezronite clan; from Hamul, the Hamulite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These clans of Judah who were registered totaled 76,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Issachar according to their clans were: from Tola, the Tolaite clan; from Puah, the Puite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Jashub, the Jashubite clan; from Shimron, the Shimronite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These clans of Issachar who were registered totaled 64,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Zebulun according to their clans were: from Sered, the Seredite clan; from Elon, the Elonite clan; from Jahle’el, the Jahle’elite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These Zebulunite clans who were registered totaled 60,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Joseph who established clans were Manasseh and Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Manasseh were: from Makir, the Makirite clan (Makir was the father of Gilead); from Gilead, the Gileadite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the male descendants of Gilead: from Iezer, the Iezerite clan; from Helek, the Helekite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Asriel, the Asrielite clan; from Shechem, the Shechemite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Shemida, the Shemidaite clan; and from Hepher, the Hepherite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zelophehad the son of Hepher had no sons, only daughters. The names of Zelophehad’s daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milkah, and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Manasseh. Those who were registered totaled 52,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the male descendants of Ephraim according to their clans: from Shuthelah, the Shuthelahite clan; from Beker, the Bekerite clan; from Tahan, the Tahanite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the male descendants of Shuthelah: from Eran, the Eranite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These clans from the descendants of Ephraim who were registered totaled 32,500.
These were the male descendants of Joseph according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Benjamin according to their clans were: from Bela, the Belaite clan; from Ashbel, the Ashbelite clan; from Ahiram, the Ahiramite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Shupham, the Shuphamite clan; from Hupham, the Huphamite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bela were Ard and Na’aman: from Ard, the Ardite clan; from Na’aman, the Na’amanite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the male descendants of Benjamin according to their clans. Those who were registered totaled 45,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the male descendants of Dan according to their clans: from Shuham, the Shuhamite clan. These were the clans of Dan according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Shuhamite clans who were registered totaled 64,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Asher according to their clans were: from Imnah, the Imnite clan; from Ishvi, the Ishvite clan; from Beriah, the Beriite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the male descendants of Beriah: from Heber, the Heberite clan; from Malkiel, the Malkielite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Asher’s daughter was Serah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These clans for the descendants of Asher who were registered totaled 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male descendants of Naphtali according to their clans were: from Jahze’el, the Jahze’elite clan; from Guni, the Gunite clan;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Jezer, the Jezerite clan; from Shillem, the Shillemite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the clans of Naphtali according to their clans. Those who were registered totaled 45,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were registered from the Israelites totaled 601,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The land is to be divided among these tribes, with the size of the possession for each tribe based on the number of names.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a larger tribe, increase its possession. For a smaller tribe, decrease its possession. Each tribe is to be given its inheritance based on the total of those registered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land must be divided by lot. They will receive their possession according to the names of their father’s tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their possession is to be divided between the larger and the smaller tribes as the lots determine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were registered from the Levites according to their clans were: from Gershon, the Gershonite clan; from Kohath, the Kohathite clan; from Merari, the Merarite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the Levite clans: the Libnite clan, the Hebronite clan, the Mahlite clan, the Mushite clan, the Korahite clan.
(Kohath was the forefather of Amram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, a descendant of Levi, who was born to the Levites in Egypt. For Amram she bore Aaron, Moses, and their sister Miriam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar were born to Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu died when they presented unauthorized fire before the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were registered totaled 23,000, every male a month old and up. But they were not registered with the other Israelites, because they were not given a possession among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men who were registered by Moses and Eleazar the priest, when they registered the Israelites on the Plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: But among them there was not even one man left from those who had been registered by Moses and Aaron the priest, when they registered the Israelites in the Wilderness of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said about them, “They will surely die in the wilderness.” There was not even one man left from them except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the daughters of Zelophehad came forward. (Zelophehad was the son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Makir, the son of Manasseh, from the clans of Manasseh the son of Joseph.) These were the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milkah, and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stood at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting before Moses and Eleazar the priest, before the tribal chiefs and the entire community. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father died in the wilderness. He was not among the company of those who gathered together against the Lord along with the followers of Korah, but he died in his own sin. He had no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should the name of our father be taken away from a place among his clan, because he had no son? Give us property among our father’s brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought their case before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “What the daughters of Zelophehad say is correct. You must give them property as an inheritance among their father’s brothers. You are to allow their father’s inheritance to be passed down to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to tell the Israelites, ‘If a man dies and has no son, then you are to have his inheritance pass down to his daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no daughter, then you will give his inheritance to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no brothers, then you will give his inheritance to his father’s brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his father has no brothers, then you will give his inheritance to his closest relative from his clan, and he will take possession of it. This will be a legal statute for the Israelites, just as the Lord commanded Moses.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go up onto this mountain in the Abarim range and see the land which I have given to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you have seen it, you yourself will also be gathered to your people just as Aaron your brother was gathered.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when the community quarreled in the Wilderness of Zin, you both rebelled against my command to honor me as holy in their sight at the waters.” (This refers to the waters of Meribah Kadesh in the Wilderness of Zin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses spoke to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: “May the Lord, the God of the spirits of all flesh, appoint a man over the community,
speaker: Narrator

text: who will go out before them and come in before them, who will lead them out and bring them in, so that the community of the Lord will not be like sheep without a shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take Joshua son of Nun, a man in whom is the Spirit, and place your hand on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the entire community. You will commission him in their sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give some of your authority to him so that the entire Israelite community will listen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will stand before Eleazar the priest, who will inquire for him before the Lord with the decision of the Urim. He and all the Israelites with him, the entire community, will go out at his command and come in at his command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did just as the Lord commanded him. He took Joshua and had him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the entire community.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed his hands on him and commissioned him, just as the Lord spoke through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Moses
speaker: Narrator

text:
to deliver this command to the Israelites:
Make sure that you present my offering at its appointed time. Present it as my food, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, “This is the offering made by fire that you shall present to the Lord each day: two one-year-old male lambs without defect as a regular burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to offer one lamb in the morning, and you are to offer the other lamb at twilight,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with two quarts of fine flour as a grain offering, mixed with one quart of oil from beaten olives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the regular burnt offering put into effect at Mount Sinai for a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The drink offering with it is to be one quart for one lamb. You are to pour out the drink offering of beer to the Lord at the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to prepare the other lamb at twilight. You are to prepare it along with the same kind of grain offering and drink offering as in the morning, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the Sabbath day, you shall present two one-year-old male lambs without defect, four quarts of fine flour mixed with oil as a grain offering, and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the whole burnt offering for every Sabbath, in addition to the regular burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the beginning of each of your months, you shall present as a whole burnt offering to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old male lambs without defect,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with six quarts of fine flour mixed with oil as a grain offering for each bull; four quarts of fine flour mixed with oil as a grain offering for the one ram;
speaker: Narrator

text: and two quarts of fine flour mixed with oil as a grain offering for every lamb—as a burnt offering with a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their drink offerings will be two quarts of wine for a bull, a quart and a half for a ram, and one quart for a lamb. This is the monthly burnt offering for each month of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: One male goat is to be presented as a sin offering to the Lord in addition to the regular burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month, the fourteenth day of the month is the Passover for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of this month there is to be a festival. Unleavened bread is to be eaten for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first day is to be a holy convocation. You are not to do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present an offering made by fire, a burnt offering to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil: six quarts for a bull and four quarts for the ram.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will prepare two quarts for each of the seven lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one male goat as a sin offering to make atonement for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will prepare these things in addition to the morning burnt offering that is part of the regular burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way for seven days you will prepare food daily as an offering made by fire with a pleasing aroma to the Lord. It is to be prepared in addition to the regular burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day there is to be a holy convocation. You shall not do any of your regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day of the firstfruits when you present an offering of new grain to the Lord during the Festival of Weeks, you shall have a holy convocation. You shall not do any of your regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present as a whole burnt offering for a pleasing aroma to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old male lambs
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering, fine flour mixed with oil: six quarts for each bull, four quarts for the one ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two quarts for each of the seven lambs;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat to make atonement for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to offer these and their drink offerings in addition to the regular burnt offering and its grain offering. Your animals are to be without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you shall have a holy convocation. You shall not do any of your regular work. For you it is to be a day of loud blasts on the ram’s horn.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to prepare a whole burnt offering as a pleasing aroma to the Lord: one young bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering, fine flour mixed with oil: six quarts for the bull, four quarts for the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two quarts for each of the seven lambs;
speaker: Narrator

text: also prepare one male goat for a sin offering to make atonement for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is in addition to the monthly burnt offering and its grain offering, the regular burnt offering and its grain offering, and their drink offerings, just as specified, for a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of this seventh month you shall have a holy convocation. You shall humble yourselves. You are not to do any kind of work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present a whole burnt offering to the Lord, a pleasing aroma: one young bull, one ram, seven one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering, fine flour mixed with oil: six quarts for the bull, four quarts for the one ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: two quarts for each of the seven lambs;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the sin offering of atonement, the regular burnt offering and its grain offering, and their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month you shall have a holy convocation. You are not to do any of your regular work. You shall celebrate a pilgrimage festival to the Lord for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present a whole burnt offering, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord: thirteen young bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering, fine flour mixed with oil: six quarts for each of the thirteen bulls, four quarts for each of the two rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two quarts for each of the fourteen lambs;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second day you are to present twelve young bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day you are to present eleven bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day you are to present ten bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth day you are to present nine bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day you are to present eight bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day you are to present seven bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day you shall hold a closing ceremony. You shall not do any of your regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present a burnt offering, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord: one bull, one ram, seven one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bull, the ram, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to your offerings to fulfill a vow and freewill offerings, you shall prepare these for the Lord at your appointed times as your burnt offerings, your grain offerings, your drink offerings, and your fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told the Israelites everything that the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also gave the heads of the Israelite tribes these commands from the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man makes a vow to the Lord or swears an oath to put himself under an obligation, he must not break his word. He must do everything that has come out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a woman, while living in her father’s house during her youth, makes a vow to the Lord and puts herself under an obligation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her father hears about her vow and her obligation which she has undertaken, but her father says nothing to her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation which she has undertaken will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father forbids her on the same day that he hears about them, none of her vows nor her obligations which she has undertaken will stand. The Lord will forgive her, because her father has forbidden her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she marries a husband while she is obligated by a vow or something she spoke rashly,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her on the same day that he hears about it, then her vows will stand, and her obligations which she has undertaken will be binding.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband forbids her on the same day that he hears about it, he will nullify her vow which obligates her and her responsibility for the things she spoke rashly. The Lord will forgive her.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the vow of a widow or a divorced woman, every obligation which she put herself under, will be binding on her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, while she is still in her husband’s house, she took a vow or put herself under an obligation with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her and does not forbid her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation under which she has put herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband does indeed nullify them on the same day that he hears about them, then whatever came from her lips concerning her vows or her obligation will not stand. Her husband has nullified them. The Lord will forgive her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband may allow or nullify every vow or every oath in which she undertakes an obligation to deny herself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband indeed says nothing to her from day to day, then he confirms all her vows or all her obligations, which are binding on her. He has allowed them, because he said nothing to her on the day that he hears about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he nullifies them later than the day he hears about them, then he will bear her responsibility.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the statutes which the Lord commanded Moses about vows pertaining to a husband and his wife, or a father and his daughter during her youth while she still lives at her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take vengeance against the Midianites for the Israelites. After that, you will be gathered to your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses spoke to the people, “Equip some of your men for combat. They will go against Midian to carry out the Lord’s vengeance on Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send one thousand men from each of the tribes of Israel into combat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So out of all the thousands of Israel, a military unit of a thousand was selected from each tribe—a total of twelve thousand men armed for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent them into combat, one thousand from each tribe. Moses sent them and Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, into combat. Things from the sanctuary and the trumpets for signaling were in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fought against Midian, as the Lord commanded Moses, and they killed every male.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with the others who were slain, they killed the kings of Midian: Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba, the five kings of Midian. They also killed Balaam son of Beor with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites took the women of Midian and their children captive. They plundered all their animals, property, and possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: They burned all their cities where they settled and all their camps.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all the plunder and all the spoils of war, both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the captives, the spoils of war, and the plunder to Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the Israelite community at the camp on the Plains of Moab, which was by the Jordan across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the tribal chiefs of the community went out to meet them outside of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was angry with the officers of the army—the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds—who were coming back from the military campaign.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “Have you allowed every woman to live?
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, following Balaam’s advice, these women were the ones who incited the Israelites to be unfaithful to the Lord in the Peor incident, and so the plague came upon the community of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, kill every male among the children, and kill every woman who has had sexual relations with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you may keep alive for yourselves all the young females who have not had sexual relations with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All of you who have killed a person or touched a slain body shall stay outside of the camp for seven days. Purify yourselves and your captives on the third day and on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also purify every garment, every leather item, everything made of goat hair, and every item of wood.”
speaker: Narrator
